data.title: Notify on auto refresh of open file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Is it possible to add the auto-refresh feature in a future version of the Visual Studio Code?
For example, if I'm reading a log file to check up on errors and this file is updated outside the editor, the Visual Studio Code could warn about the changes on the file, like Visual Studio already does.

data.title: Squiggle covering EOL gets rendered on two lines
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (f6ab171ab619a988b84fd1b91bb76e65847115a2, 2017-05-12T06:11:44.129Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type a line of code in the editor
2. Have the extension send a textDocument/publishDiagnostics message with a problem reported at the end of the line

For example, Visual Studio does this:
![eol-squiggle1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12818240/26068837/bd32ac0c-3953-11e7-8a5c-defd731aba4c.png)

If I send a problem to VS Code with the character pointing to the EOL character, no squiggle is drawn on that line:
![eol-squiggle2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12818240/26068873/dd7e0182-3953-11e7-8023-e49daad0db1b.png)

data.title: Add way to open Markdown links in a different editor group
data.body:
Scenario:

Markdown file is open in left editor group.  This file has a lot of links to other .md files that I want to preview in the right editor group.  But  Markdown links can currently only be opened into the same editor.

Please consider.  Thanks!

data.title: Add input active and inactive background color to input boxes
data.body:
You have "input.border" and "focusBorder" to differentiate between active and inactive input boxes. A better option is to have something like "input.activeBackground" and "input.inactiveBackground" to differentiate between the focused input box with other input boxes.

With it something like this can be achieved (Nord theme, Atom)
![drac](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/26769888/26064126/a8766f42-39ad-11e7-8bc2-55e5e01ea236.gif)

data.title: [theme] remove editorOptions.theme
data.body:
@alexandrudima As mentioned in the standup, I'd like to remove editorOptions.theme as theme configuration is now done through the themeService.

editorOption.theme got replaced by editorOption.extraEditorClassName as the diff editor uses the theme field to add an additional class name. I migrated all users of editorOption.theme to the theme service. I preserved any updating/rerender logic, even for some cases this could be reviewed.

Please have a look at the changes to the standalone editor.
I kept 'theme' on the `IEditorConstructionOptions` so to stay compatible with the old API where users can create an editor and set the theme at the same time.
However, switching a theme while the editor is open now needs to be done through a new API `monaco.editor.setTheme`.

data.title: 'Reveal in Explorer' key shortcut does not behave as context menu item
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open folder in workspace, go to Explorer viewlet
2. Right click on the empty space within the viewlet
3. Select 'Reveal in Explorer (Alt+Shift+R)' -> **Folder opened in Explorer**

Now do step 2 again and use 'Alt+Shift+R' shortcut -> **Folder is not opened in Explorer**.

If I use Command Prompt + Format Document the file gets formatted.

data.title: Using Spanish locale on Mac shows "Open new command prompt" instead of "Open new terminal" underneath Spanish text
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:18:32.269Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0 - Extensions: |Extension|Author|Version| |---|---|---| |material-icon-theme|PKief|2.0.5| |vscode-theme-onedark|akamud|1.3.2| |monokai-plusplus|dcasella|1.6.0| |githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0| |theme-dracula|dracula-theme|1.17.0| |php-intellisense|felixfbecker|1.2.1| |ftp-sync|lukasz-wronski|0.3.3| |typescript-javascript-grammar|ms-vscode|0.0.19| |language-stylus|sysoev|1.7.2| |twig|whatwedo|1.0.2| |Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|2.7.5|; --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set Spanish locale (I ran the "Configure Language" command and set "locale":"es" 2. Restart VS code to load new locale 3. Open the command palette and type "terminal" after the existing ">" When using VS code in English, the text just displays "Open new terminal", which makes sense given that it is called Terminal on macOS and not Command Prompt as it is in Windows. However, when using the Spanish locale, the Spanish text is correct but the English underneath appears to display the text for a Windows machine (showing Command Prompt)

- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|angular-material-snippets|4tron|0.3.1|
|aessoft-class-autocomplete|AESSoft|0.1.0|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|ruby-on-rails-snippets|atefth|0.0.1|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|vscode-html-css|ecmel|0.1.4|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|2.1.2|
|auto-close-tag|formulahendry|0.4.1|
|path-autocomplete|ionutvmi|1.4.1|
|css-classes|joelfmrodrigues|0.0.1|
|Angular1|johnpapa|0.1.16|
|vscode-rust|kalitaalexey|0.3.14|
|es6-angular-snips|kasperkeso|0.0.3|
|remote-vscode|rafaelmaiolla|1.0.1|
|Ruby|rebornix|0.12.1|
|ruby-snippet|robert|0.1.0|
|standard|shinnn|0.2.3|
|html-preview-vscode|tht13|0.1.1|
|python|tht13|0.2.3|
|colonize|vmsynkov|2.2.2|
|JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.4.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open vscode on Macbook Pro(Japanese keyboard layout)
2. Connect external keyboard(English keyboard layout)
3. When push the `⌘ + \` on Macbook Pro keyboard, it worked the `⌘ + \` shortcut. (correct)
4. When push the `⌘ + ]` on external keyboard, it worked the `⌘ + [` shortcut. (incorrect)
5. When push the `⌘ + \` on external keyboard, it worked the `⌘ + ]` shortcut. (incorrect)

data.title: Bug: cannot open vscode while using 'code .'
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows Sever 2012R2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open command prompt(**admin**).
2. change directory to workspace A.
3. run 'code .' to open vscode (works well).
4. open command prompt(**not admin**).
5. change directory to workspace B.
6. run 'code .' to open vscode (does not work).

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:26:50.689Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393 - Extensions: |Extension|Author|Version| |---|---|---| |django-html|bibhasdn|1.2.0| |django-snippets|bibhasdn|1.1.0| |python|donjayamanne|0.6.4| |beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2| |MagicPython|magicstack|1.0.10| |python|tht13|0.2.3| |python-extended-snippets|tushortz|0.0.1| |jinja|wholroyd|0.0.8|; --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. data.title: Npm install fails during finalize with VS Code Open.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code
2. Run npm install in a directory currently open in VS Code

Npm install will run through to the finalize stage at which point:
`Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, rename` for some library is thrown. The library installing when this error occurs varies with each install.

Closing VS code and running npm install again will work correctly.

1. git clone 
2. ./scripts/npm.sh install
3. npm run compile

error about `not find module @types/node`

So did you use `@types/node` as a global module and not add to the package.json?

data.title: [json] Incorrect brace matching in JSON files
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:
Version 1.12.1
Commit f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b
Date 2017-05-04T21:40:39.245Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0

- OS Version:
Linux Mint 18.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create the following .json file:
```
{
	"foo": [
		{
			"[": {}
		},
		1,
		{"{":"a"},
		3
	]
}
```
2. click braces `}` and or `]` to highlight corresponding opening braces ... notice it matches the braces embedded in strings.

data.title: [Feature request] Add Tag for Extensions
data.body:
Request feature.

Add "Tag" for extensions, then we can click Tag to find relate extensions.


_English is not my language, so I'm not sure it should be "Tag" or "Label"._

data.title: Search: unable to include/exclude via glob patterns
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. "Find in folder"
2. append a *.css at the end to enable glob matching

=> you get an unhelpful error like this one:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/26044242/6b284364-3943-11e7-8cd3-d27768398be0.png)

This used to work previously without having to enable the glob option. I would just detect glob patterns in the pattern and remove the leading `./`, that seems to fix it.
